title: Lab to determine effective k of springs

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are to perform an experiment to determine the effective spring constant of the two springs, <math alttext="k sub effective" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown above. The students are expected to find the effective spring constant, <math alttext="k sub effective" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes two ideal springs with spring constants <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="k sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a block of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which slides across a surface where friction can be neglected. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

Students are to perform an experiment to determine the effective spring constant of the two springs, <math alttext="k sub effective" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown above. The students are expected to find the effective spring constant, <math alttext="k sub effective" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes two ideal springs with spring constants <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="k sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a block of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which slides across a surface where friction can be neglected. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the effective spring constant, <math alttext="k sub effective" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the effective spring constant, <math alttext="k sub effective" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how that information would be used to determine the effective spring constant, <math alttext="k sub effective" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Another group of students perform the same experiment, but instead of placing the setup horizontally, they attach the block to the springs and hang the springs vertically from the ceiling. Will the value of the effective spring constant, <math alttext="k sub effective" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the vertical setup be greater than, less than, or equal to the value of the effective spring constant for the horizontal setup?
